column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; THE WHITE HOUSE WASHINGTON June 21, 1996 MEMORANDUM FOR T.J. GLAUTHIER FROM: Carol Rasco SUBJECT: Family Right to Know Initiative; ; The Family Right to Know Initiative is a very positive concept that has the potential to fill an important void in the current protection of children's health from environmental risks. When parents and families know about the unique risks to children they can use that information to make wise choices. Responsible decisions by parents can have an aggregate benefit today and in the future.
column5: The above memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication within the White House, and as such, may contain deliberative or pre-decisional information that is exempt from disclosure. Additionally, the memorandum may be covered by the presidential communications privilege, which protects communications between the President and his advisors. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004). In that case, the court held that a memorandum from the White House Counsel's Office to the President regarding the investigation of a former White House intern was protected by the deliberative process privilege under FOIA exemption 5. The court noted that the memorandum was "predecisional and deliberative" and that its disclosure would "chill the candor of future deliberations within the White House." ; ; Similarly, in Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 97 F.3d 575 (D.C. Cir. 1996), the court held that a memorandum from White House counsel to the President regarding an investigation into the Whitewater affair was protected by the presidential communications privilege. The court noted that the memorandum was "solicited and received by the President in the course of his official duties" and that its disclosure would "inhibit the candor necessary for effective presidential decisionmaking." ; ; Based on these cases, it is likely that the memorandum regarding the Family Right to Know Initiative would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

GLAUTHIER FROM: Carol Rasco SUBJECT: Family Right to Know Initiative; ; In framing this concept we have agreed to a commitment to work with parents, scientists, the business community, and others to achieve the goals of getting better information to families. As we work with the stakeholders we can build on the concept of a family's right to know, and decide whether legislation is or is not needed to achieve our goals. As the Administration moves forward we should continue to emphasize our belief that we can achieve our goals in a common sense, cost effective way. That emphasis is needed to respond to concerns that we will put into place unnecessarily expensive approaches. I plan to continue to be involved in this initiative; please contact Diane Regas of my staff with new information as it arises.

Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE (1981), in which the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals held that the privilege applies to "predecisional, deliberative communications that are part of the agency's decision-making process." ; ; Therefore, unless there is a compelling public interest in disclosure that outweighs the government's interest in protecting the deliberative process, the statement in question would likely be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: Yes, the above statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column5: Yes, this document would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The document appears to be an internal communication between White House staff members discussing environmental issues for the State of the Union address. As such, it may contain deliberative or pre-decisional information that is exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure.; ; Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "give-and-take" of the decision-making process, including the "free and frank exchange of views" among agency officials.; ; Based on these cases, it seems likely that the White House memorandum discussing environmental issues for the State of the Union would be protected under exemption 5 as a privileged communication within the agency.

The government's role is limited to identifying which substances are of concern, and perhaps identifying level below which labeling will not .be required. column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum is a communication between White House staff members regarding environmental issues for the State of the Union address, which would likely be considered an internal agency communication. Additionally, the memorandum appears to contain advice and recommendations, which are typically protected under the deliberative process privilege.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process of an agency. Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that the privilege applies to communications that are predecisional and deliberative in nature.

I'm sure Melissa S. will have an interest in this, and Treasury will want to be part of these discussions as well.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The discussion of potential issues to consider and the need to put together a position paper suggests that this is a deliberative process aimed at developing policy recommendations. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The text in question appears to fit within this definition.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between individuals within the Executive Office of the President (EOP) regarding a news article or report about a House of Representatives statement on child care for stay-at-home mothers. The content of the communication is not provided, so it is unclear whether it contains privileged information or legal advice. However, if the communication does contain privileged information or legal advice, it could be protected under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they are part of the agency's decision-making process and reflect the agency's internal deliberations. The Court also held that the exemption covers communications that are "privileged," meaning they are protected by a recognized legal privilege, such as the attorney-client privilege or the work product doctrine. If the communication in this record meets these criteria, it could be protected under exemption 5.

column5: It is possible that the above message could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The key factor in determining whether this exemption applies is whether the communication contains predecisional or deliberative information that would be protected from disclosure in order to preserve the agency's decision-making process. ; ; In this case, the message appears to be a summary of a meeting about child care, and it is unclear from the limited information provided whether it contains any predecisional or deliberative information. However, if the message includes discussions of potential policy options or recommendations, or if it reflects internal agency deliberations about how to approach a particular issue, it could be considered protected under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this interpretation is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 applies to "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Other cases have similarly emphasized the importance of protecting internal agency communications that are part of the decision-making process, even if they are not the final decision itself. ; ; Ultimately, the determination of whether this particular message is protected under exemption 5 would depend on a more detailed analysis of its contents and context.

I think we do not -- we want to encourage states to develop seamless child care systems that focus on incomes, not categories. In that case. what is the best way to encourage states to develop seamless systems? I think it is not by setting benchmarks or other rules which encourage the new funds to be used for the not-formerly-on-welfare working poor to counterbalance current practice of focusing dollars on former welfare recipients.  I think it is by providing funds for states to raise their eligibility criteria to include more low-income families.

Rice 12/02/97 09:45:30 PM Record Type: Record To: See the distribution list at the bottom of this message cc: Diana Fortuna/OPD/EOP, Andrea Kane/OPD/EOP Subject: A few thoughts on today's child care meeting; ; Stay at Home Parents Regarding stay-at-home parents, I will admit I am completely unschooled in this issue. I do think we will be able to argue that we are helping stay-at-home parents through the $500 per child tax credit. I do also think, as I think you do, that an additional proposal here would be very helpful. I think such a proposal should focus on parents who stay home for more than 6-24 weeks. Thus, I would like to see something like the demonstration project idea, which would provide funds to community and religious groups (including the latter would be helpful) who provide support and assistance to stay-at-home parents, by offering parenting classes or hotlines, play groups, two hour “relief” or “emergency” child care, or which distribute materials to new parents (I though Barry’s idea of promoting connections to WIC was promising).

Additionally, in Public Citizen v. OMB (D.C. Cir. 1996), the court held that exemption 5 applies to communications that are part of the agency's decision-making process, even if they are not directly related to a specific decision.

This would allow local organizations to provide culturally-sensitive programs for parents of particularly ethnicities, which the Hispanic caucus encouraged us to do. In fact, in my in-box is the new issue of Univ of Wisconsin Institute on Poverty magazine which highlights an evaluation of a program called Avance that has worked with low-income Hispanic infants and their families in San Antonio since 1973 which has the explicit goal of "helping mothers become better teachers of their children." The evaluation found "positive and significant differences between participant and control mothers on three measures of teaching effectiveness." I can fax you a copy if you like (it's only one page).

column5: It is possible that the message would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without more information about the content of the message, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the message contains legal advice or attorney-client communications, it may be protected under the attorney-client privilege or the work product doctrine. In that case, it would likely be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; However, if the message contains purely factual information or policy discussions, it may not be protected under exemption 5. ; ; Case law that may be relevant includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the deliberative process privilege as a component of exemption 5. This privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process within an agency, and are therefore considered pre-decisional and deliberative. However, the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in keeping the communication confidential.

column5: It is possible that the message sent to Elena Kagan, Jennifer L. Klein, Nicole R. Rabner, Neera Tanden, and Laura Emmett regarding proposed legislation regarding Nazi war criminals could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This would depend on whether the communication was made in the course of the agency's decision-making process and whether it reflects the agency's deliberative process.; ; There is no case law cited in the prompt to support a conclusion either way. However, courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 broadly to protect the internal decision-making processes of agencies. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional, deliberative communications that are part of the agency's decision-making process."; ; Based on these precedents, it is possible that the communication regarding proposed legislation regarding Nazi war criminals could be protected under exemption 5 if it reflects the agency's deliberative process and was made in the course of the agency's decision-making process. However, without more information about the content and context of the communication, it is impossible to say for certain whether it would be protected.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; SOCIAL SECURITY Office of the Commissioner April 25, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO: Bruce Reed Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy SUBJECT: Proposed Legislation Regarding Nazi War criminals; ; I must convey to you in the strongest possible terms that we should proceed to introduce  legislation that will deny Social Security benefits to all Nazi war criminals who are denaturalized · on the basis of having participated in Nazi persecution. Currently, Nazi war criminals who have  been denaturalized, but flee prior to the issuance of a final order of deportation, may continue to  collect Social Security benefits. The Social Security Administration (SSA) and the Department of  Justice staff have drafted corrective legislation. Such legislation should go forward without delay.
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The memorandum is an intra-agency communication between the Social Security Administration and the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy, and it contains deliberative and pre-decisional information regarding proposed legislation. The memorandum reflects the agency's internal discussions and recommendations, and its disclosure could harm the agency's decision-making process. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which held that exemption 5 protects documents that are both pre-decisional and deliberative, and that disclosure of such documents would inhibit the free flow of ideas within an agency. Additionally, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are part of the agency's decision-making process, even if they are not directly related to a specific decision.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; SOCIAL SECURITY Office of the Commissioner April 25, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO: Bruce Reed Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy SUBJECT: Proposed Legislation Regarding Nazi War criminals; ; While some groups have contended that such legislation could complicate the Government's ability to track down and successfully prosecute Nazi war criminals in this country, I find that contention difficult to accept. The federal government must pursue denaturalization and deportation against Nazi war criminals without any reference to whether or not they should receive Social Security benefits. Social Security benefits cannot, and should not, be used as a bargaining tool.
column5: The above memorandum would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. This memorandum does not fall under this exemption because it does not involve any deliberative process or contain any pre-decisional or post-decisional information. It is a communication from the Office of the Commissioner of Social Security to the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy regarding proposed legislation. There is no indication that this memorandum contains any confidential or privileged information that would be exempt from disclosure under FOIA. Therefore, it should be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; Case law: In Tax Analysts v. IRS, the Supreme Court held that FOIA exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both pre-decisional and deliberative. The Court stated that "the exemption is designed to protect the decision-making processes of government agencies, not to shield information from public view." Therefore, the memorandum in question would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5 because it does not involve any deliberative process or contain any pre-decisional or post-decisional information.

This exemption is intended to protect the decision-making process of government agencies by allowing them to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure.; ; In this case, the memorandum is an intra-agency communication from the Office of the Commissioner of Social Security to the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy. It is discussing proposed legislation regarding Nazi war criminals, which is likely a sensitive and controversial topic. The memorandum is also a request for a meeting to discuss the issue, which suggests that there may be further deliberations and decision-making to take place.; ; There is case law that supports the application of exemption 5 to similar types of intra-agency communications. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 applied to internal memoranda and reports that were part of the decision-making process of the National Labor Relations Board. The Court reasoned that disclosure of such materials would inhibit the free flow of ideas and opinions within the agency, which would harm the agency's ability to make informed decisions.; ; Therefore, it is likely that the above memorandum would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

The content of the memorandum is not provided, so it is unclear whether it contains any deliberative or pre-decisional information that would be protected under exemption 5.; ; However, there is case law that supports the application of exemption 5 to similar types of intra-agency communications. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protected internal memoranda within the National Labor Relations Board that contained recommendations and opinions regarding pending cases. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This includes materials that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, as well as those that are "part of the agency's decision-making process." ; ; In addition, in Tax Analysts v. IRS, 492 U.S. 136 (1989), the Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." This suggests that the fact sheet may be protected if it contains advisory opinions or recommendations related to the Social Security Administration's policies regarding Nazi war criminals and Social Security benefits. ; ; Overall, while it is difficult to say for certain without more information about the content of the fact sheet, it is likely that it would be protected under exemption 5.

Callahan Acting Commissioner Social Security Administration SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION WASHINGTON DC 20254; ; • Since the 1980's, the law has provided that Social Security benefits must be cut off when a final order of deportation is issued against an individual because that individual engaged in Nazi persecution or genocide. This provision of Social Security law is specifically for Nazi war criminals and provides for an earlier cut off than for other deportees, whose benefits are not cut off until they are actually deported.
column5: The information provided in the letter would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The letter appears to be a communication between government officials regarding the interpretation and implementation of Social Security law, which could be considered privileged. Additionally, the information relates to a specific provision of law that is intended to address a sensitive and controversial issue (Nazi war criminals), which could further support a claim of exemption under FOIA.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that FOIA exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the "deliberative process" of government decision-making, which includes the exchange of opinions, recommendations, and other communications among agency officials. This reasoning would likely apply to the letter from the Acting Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, as it appears to be a communication among agency officials regarding the interpretation and implementation of a specific provision of law.; ; Another case that supports this conclusion is Tax Analysts v. IRS, 117 F.3d 607 (D.C. Cir. 1997), in which the D.C. Circuit held that FOIA exemption 5 covers "predecisional" and "deliberative" documents that are "generated before the adoption of an agency policy and reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to engage in frank and candid discussions without fear of public disclosure. This reasoning would also likely apply to the letter from the Acting Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, as it appears to be a communication among agency officials regarding the interpretation and implementation of a specific provision of law that could have significant policy implications.

column5: The information provided in the letter would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Specifically, the information appears to be related to internal agency deliberations and decision-making processes regarding the enforcement of Social Security law and the handling of individuals who may have escaped prosecution for war crimes. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370 (D.C. Cir. 2007), in which the court held that information related to the CIA's internal deliberations and decision-making processes regarding the use of enhanced interrogation techniques was protected under FOIA exemption 5. The court reasoned that disclosure of such information would harm the agency's ability to make informed decisions and would chill internal deliberations. Similarly, disclosure of the information in the letter could harm the Social Security Administration's ability to make informed decisions and could chill internal deliberations regarding the enforcement of Social Security law and the handling of individuals who may have escaped prosecution for war crimes. ; ; Additionally, the information in the letter may also be protected under FOIA exemption 7(E), which covers law enforcement records that would disclose techniques and procedures for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions, or would disclose guidelines for law enforcement investigations or prosecutions if such disclosure could reasonably be expected to risk circumvention of the law. However, this exemption would only apply if the information in the letter was created for law enforcement purposes.

Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975). In that case, the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege, which is a component of exemption 5, protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The Court explained that the purpose of the privilege is to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing agency officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure.; ; Based on this case law and the limited information provided in the record, it is possible that the record could be protected under exemption 5. However, a more thorough analysis would be necessary to make a definitive determination.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Stephen C. Warnath Record Type: Record To: Elena Kagan/OPO/EOP cc: Subject: SSA benefits and Nazi War Criminals; ; In my follow-up with the White House attendees at the meeting, we agree that the specific enforcement concern depends on predictions on what judges may or may not do and therefore does not sound fully compelling EXCEPT that it is impossible to ignore who is raising the concern. These individuals are representatives of those who are the most concerned about and the most effected by this proposal. It gains us very little to close this SSA loophole if taking that action is decried in the strongest possible terms by the victims of those war criminals as undermining their prosecutions.
column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The language in the record suggests that it may contain internal deliberations or legal advice related to the proposed SSA loophole closure and its potential impact on the prosecution of Nazi war criminals. However, without more context it is difficult to determine whether this record meets the requirements for exemption 5 protection.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which established that exemption 5 applies to materials that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. This means that the record must be created before a final decision is made and must reflect the agency's internal thought processes and decision-making considerations. Additionally, the record must be the type of communication that would be protected by a recognized privilege if it occurred between private parties.; ; Based on the limited information provided, it is unclear whether this record meets all of these requirements. Further analysis would be necessary to determine whether it is exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.

They would make sure that it is known that the President has introduced legislation that would compromise the prosecutions of Nazis.
column5: The text provided would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The text provided does not appear to be an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter, but rather a communication between individuals outside of a government agency. Therefore, FOIA exemption 5 would not apply.; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that FOIA exemption 5 only applies to inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters, and not to other types of records.

There is already at least one critical article that has appeared (St. Petersburg Times) and SSA has been contacted by a Tampa CBS affiliate for comment. I think that we can anticipate other critical pieces, and it may be picked up by the national press. Cong. Bunning (R-Ky), chair of the Ways and Means Social Security Subcommittee has requested information about the St. Petersburg story.
column5: The text provided would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The text appears to be a communication between government officials discussing potential criticism of the Social Security Administration's policies regarding payments to Nazi war criminals. The discussion of potential criticism and the agency's response to it could be considered part of the agency's decision-making process and therefore privileged. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to communicate candidly and freely without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the communication between government officials discussing potential criticism of the agency's policies would likely fall within the scope of exemption 5 as a privileged communication.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Stephen C. Warnath Record Type: Record To: Elena Kagan/OPO/EOP cc: Subject: SSA benefits and Nazi War Criminals; ; Given the foregoing considerations, I think that this is a very difficult issue, but I have to recommend to you that we provide guidance to SSA that the proposal should not go forward, Normally, I would give quite a bit of deference to Justice and SSA for the product of a solid interagency process. Nobody wants to provide benefits to Nazis, ESPECIALLY when some of their victims who are legal immigrants may face benefit cut-offs, but we cannot ignore the absolute conviction of those who we heard from who represent the victims when they say that the President will hinder the prosecutions of Nazis with this proposal.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter- or intra-agency communications that are deliberative in nature and would be privileged in civil litigation. The text appears to be a recommendation from one government official to another regarding a policy proposal, and it includes the author's thought process and analysis of the issue. This type of communication is typically considered deliberative and therefore exempt from disclosure under FOIA. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "opinions, recommendations, and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The text in question here appears to fit within this definition.

column5: It is unlikely that the above record would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a simple email communication between two individuals, and does not contain any legal advice or other privileged information. Additionally, the subject matter of the email (SSA benefits and Nazi War Criminals) does not appear to be related to any ongoing legal or policy discussions within the government. Therefore, it is unlikely that exemption 5 would apply.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this particular record, but courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 narrowly and have required agencies to demonstrate a specific privilege that applies to the requested information. For example, in FTC v. Grolier Inc., the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege (one of the privileges covered by exemption 5) only applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, the D.C. Circuit held that the attorney-client privilege (another privilege covered by exemption 5) only applies to communications that are made for the purpose of seeking or providing legal advice. Based on these and other cases, it is unlikely that the above record would be protected under exemption 5.

The loophole exists, for example, for a Nazi who flees the country without an order of deportation. Under those circumstances, SSA benefits would continue.
column5: The information in this record would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between two government officials regarding a legal issue, specifically the interpretation of a law related to SSA benefits and Nazi war criminals. This type of communication would likely be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they are part of the decision-making process and reflect the agency's internal deliberations. The communication in this record appears to be both predecisional and deliberative, as it discusses the interpretation of a law and the potential impact of a loophole on SSA benefits.; ; Another case that supports this conclusion is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "intra-agency" in nature, meaning they are between officials within the same agency. The communication in this record appears to be intra-agency, as it is between two officials within the Executive Office of the President.; ; Therefore, based on the predecisional, deliberative, and intra-agency nature of the communication in this record, it would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

As of March 15, 1997, 18 Nazi war criminals almost (2/3) were being paid Social Security benefits. SSA found other grounds to cut off benefits to two additional Nazi war criminals, but they could return to the Social Security roles and the pay status of another one is temporarily suspended.

However, without additional context or information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; If the record contains legal advice or attorney-client communications, it may be protected under exemption 5. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "confidential communications between Government attorneys and their clients in the course of their legal duties." Similarly, in Mead Data Central, Inc. v. U.S. Dept. of the Air Force, 566 F.2d 242 (D.C. Cir. 1977), the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers "communications which would be privileged in the private sector."; ; However, if the record does not contain privileged communications, it may not be protected under exemption 5. For example, in EPA v. Mink, 410 U.S. 73 (1973), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 does not cover "purely factual" information that is not "inextricably intertwined" with privileged communications.; ; In summary, whether the above record is protected under exemption 5 depends on the content of the record and whether it contains privileged communications. Without additional information, it is impossible to make a definitive determination.

They want SSA to tell them what it's doing about the problem. SSA anticipates that this may be the beginnning of a lot of bad press about how it provides money for the retirement of Nazis.
column5: The above record may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, specifically the deliberative process privilege. This privilege protects documents that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice. The record appears to be a communication between two government officials discussing a media inquiry and potential negative press. It contains opinions and recommendations on how to handle the situation, which could be considered part of the agency's decision-making process.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975). In this case, the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects documents that are "predecisional and deliberative, reflecting the give-and-take of the consultative process." The Court explained that this privilege is necessary to ensure that government officials can freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure, which could inhibit the decision-making process.; ; Therefore, the record in question may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, but it would ultimately depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Stephen C. Warnath 04/16/97 05:18:53 Record Type: Record To: Elena Kagan/OPD/EOP cc: Subject: Re: SSA benefits and Nazi War Criminals ~; ; This is a no-win situation. We are either going to be criticized for paying retirement to Nazis or we will be criticized because at least several major Jewish organizations will charge us with compromising enforcement. There is going to be critical press whatever the decision is. The straight policy call is probably that we should be able to rely upon the Department of Justice to determine the appropriate enforcement assessment and what will or won't damage prosecutions. And DOJ says they have struck the right balance. However, I don't think that the policy determination can be completely divorced from an assessment of the political overlay on this issue.

column5: It is possible that this communication could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The mention of setting up a meeting and discussing the matter directly could suggest that the communication is part of an ongoing deliberative process within the agency. However, without more context it is difficult to determine whether this communication meets the requirements for exemption 5 protection.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court also established a two-part test for determining whether a communication is protected under exemption 5: (1) the communication must be predecisional, meaning that it was made before the agency made a final decision on the matter; and (2) the communication must be deliberative, meaning that it reflects the agency's thought processes and decision-making strategies.; ; Based on this case law, it is possible that the communication in question could be protected under exemption 5 if it meets the predecisional and deliberative criteria. However, more information would be needed to make a definitive determination.

Rice/OPD/EOP, Jose Cerda III/OPD/EOPL, Leanne A. Shimabukuro/OPD/EOP cc: Andrea Kane/OPD/EOP Subject: Food stamps and prisoners; ; Here's what I've learned so far: Under the law, prisoners are not to be included in households in determining food stamp allotments. Last year, after GAO reported that this happens too often, Congress passed a law requiring states to establish "systems to verify and ensure" that prisoners aren't counted in households. This can include data matching programs with prisons and/or SSA. The law requires all states to do this by 8/1 /98, although USDA can grant 1-year extensions to states.

As such, it does not fall within the scope of exemption 5. There is no case law cited as this is a straightforward application of the exemption.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The email appears to be a discussion among government officials about a potential issue with food stamps going to prisoners, as well as a related issue with food stamps going to the deceased. The email mentions a report from the Government Accountability Office (GAO) and a hearing being conducted by Senator Lugar. It also suggests that the USDA may need to share data with the Social Security Administration (SSA) at the hearing.; ; The key question is whether this email contains privileged communications. The fact that it was sent among government officials suggests that it may be considered an intra-agency communication, which is one type of privileged communication under exemption 5. However, it is not clear from the email itself whether the discussion is confidential or deliberative in nature. The email does not contain any legal advice or policy recommendations, which are other types of privileged communications under exemption 5.; ; There is some case law that may support the argument that this email is not protected under exemption 5. For example, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, the Supreme Court held that a document is only privileged if it is both predecisional (i.e. prepared in anticipation of a decision) and deliberative (i.e. reflecting the agency's thought processes). The email in question may not meet this standard, as it appears to be more of a factual discussion than a deliberative one.; ; Overall, it is difficult to say definitively whether this record would be protected under exemption 5 without more information about its context and purpose.

column5: The information in this memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. This type of communication is typically protected under exemption 5 because it is considered part of the decision-making process and disclosing it could harm the government's ability to make informed decisions. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Raines FROM: Barbara Chow  Chris Sauer cc: Jack Lew Diana Fortuna Peter Orszag RE: Use of SSA prisoner database for other Federal benefit programs; ; Recommendation for Executive Memorandum With respect to the four agencies, identified above, with statutory requirements to suspend benefits, an Executive Memorandum on the issue should require the agencies to conduct matches within a specified period of time with the SSA database to identify ineligible recipients on benefit rosters. Additionally, the Memorandum would require the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration to assist the agencies in whatever ways necessary to allow quick, efficient access to the SSA database. Agencies would be required to design a protocol for matches within a specified period of time, for example 90 days, and perform the first batch of matches within a specified period of time, for example six months. Thereafter, the agencies would be required to match as frequently as practicable but no less frequently than annually.

This type of communication is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." Therefore, it may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which exempts from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Supreme Court has held that this exemption covers documents that are both predecisional and deliberative, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice about the decision-making process. See NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150-51 (1975). ; ; In this case, the record appears to be a communication between government officials discussing a radio address on curtailing prisoner benefits. Therefore, it is likely that this record would be protected under exemption 5.

column5: It is possible that the following information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies, including attorney-client communications, attorney work product, and certain deliberative process materials. However, without additional context or information about the specific content of the document, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; If the document contains attorney-client communications or attorney work product related to legal advice or strategy, it could be protected under exemption 5. Similarly, if the document contains internal agency deliberations or recommendations that are pre-decisional and part of the agency's decision-making process, it could also be protected under exemption 5.; ; However, if the document contains purely factual information or historical background that is not part of any deliberative process or legal advice, it would likely not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports the application of exemption 5 includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the "deliberative process privilege," and United States v. Weber Aircraft Corp. (1976), which clarified that the privilege applies to pre-decisional materials that are both deliberative and advisory in nature. Other cases have further refined the scope of exemption 5, such as Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy (1981), which held that the privilege does not extend to purely factual information, and National Wildlife Federation v. United States Forest Service (2007), which clarified that the privilege only applies to materials that are both pre-decisional and deliberative.

For example, recently enacted Welfare Reform legislation requires the Department of Agriculture to review its food stamp rolls to ensure that incarcerated individuals are not included in monthly food stamp allotments. The Department of Veterans' Affairs, in certain instances, is required to suspend payments to beneficiaries who are in jail. On the other hand, the Railroad Retirement Board, for example. does not suspend benefits to eligible individuals who are incarcerated. Many agencies, including some of those mentioned above, and the Office of Child Support Enforcement, within the Department of Health and Human Services, also need to obtain prisoner information.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Thanks. cc: Diana Fortuna; ; Because the facilities were not aware of the requirements, many reported only once or twice a year to SSA, often the Information was Incomplete and reported manually. The prison officials viewed the requirement as another unfunded mandate. Additionally, some correctional institutions are reluctant to enter into agreements with SSA because of the potential cost to them when Incarcerated individuals lose their Medicare or Medicaid eligibility
column5: It is possible that this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The mention of "unfunded mandate" and potential costs to correctional institutions suggests that this information may involve internal deliberations or communications between agencies regarding policy decisions or legal advice. However, without more context or information about the specific documents in question, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court also noted that the exemption is intended to protect "the decision-making processes of government agencies," but that it should be narrowly construed to avoid "frustrating the basic purpose of the Freedom of Information Act to open agency action to the light of public scrutiny."

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? The internal processes were fragmented and lacked adequate controls and most tasks were manual. This resulted in the inability to stop payments to prisoners in a timely manner. Even when agreements were in place, SSA lacked a method for monitoring the facilities' compliance.
column5: The statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Specifically, the statement appears to be discussing internal processes and controls within the Social Security Administration (SSA), which could be considered deliberative and pre-decisional in nature. As such, they may be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5 to protect the agency's decision-making process.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The statement in question appears to fit within this definition, as it discusses internal processes and controls that could inform the agency's decision-making.; ; Additionally, the fact that the statement was cc'd to Diana Fortuna suggests that it was an internal communication within the agency, further supporting the argument that it would be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Thanks. cc: Diana Fortuna; ; RESULTS TO DATE Under this Administration, SSA initiated an aggressive course of action that has resulted in significant improvements in the prisoner suspension process. Over the past few years, SSA has completed a major initiative to contact and establish agreements with all correctional facilities across the United States. As a result of this, SSA has agreements with the Federal Bureau of Prisons, all State prisons and the 25 largest local jail systems to provide us prisoner data. In addition, the Agency has agreements with over 3,500 local jails. SSA has worked with Governors, heads of correctional institutions, correctional associations and similar stakeholders to obtain their help and support in providing prisoner data on a regular basis. The cooperation of State and local correctional administrators is critical to the suspension process. SSA has developed an excellent working relationship with these administrators and the associations that represent them.
column5: The passage would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Additionally, the passage discusses the agency's relationships with external stakeholders, which could also be considered privileged communications. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The passage in question could be considered an intra-agency memorandum or letter, and the information contained therein would likely not be available to a party other than the agency. ; ; However, it is important to note that FOIA exemptions are subject to interpretation and can be challenged in court. Ultimately, the determination of whether the passage is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column5: It is possible that this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The language used in the passage suggests that the agency is discussing its internal efforts and strategies for enforcing eligibility requirements for Social Security and Supplemental Security Income programs. This could be considered privileged information that is exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; However, it is important to note that exemption 5 is not an absolute exemption and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure. In this case, there may be a strong public interest in understanding how the agency is enforcing eligibility requirements and preventing fraud in these programs. Therefore, it is possible that a court could order the release of this information if the public interest outweighs the agency's interest in keeping it confidential.; ; There is no specific case law cited in this passage to support a conclusion either way, but courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 narrowly and have emphasized the importance of balancing the public interest in disclosure against the agency's interest in confidentiality.

column5: The given statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. However, the given statement does not appear to be a communication between agencies or within an agency. It is a directive from the President, which is a final decision rather than a deliberative process. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law: In NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 only applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The Court further clarified that final decisions or statements are not protected under exemption 5.

column5: Yes, the above information would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget and the Commissioner of Social Security are both high-level officials within their respective agencies, and their analysis and recommendations would likely be considered privileged and confidential. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." In other words, if the information would not be discoverable in a lawsuit against the agency, it is likely protected under exemption 5. ; ; Additionally, the D.C. Circuit Court has held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional" and "deliberative" materials, meaning those that are part of the agency's decision-making process and are not yet final or official. This would likely apply to the Director's analysis and the Commissioner's proposals, as they are both part of the agencies' internal deliberations and have not yet been finalized or implemented. ; ; Therefore, it is likely that the above information would be protected under exemption 5 and not subject to disclosure under FOIA.

column5: It is possible that the above record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The mention of "FYI" and the fact that the record was sent to multiple individuals within the Executive Office of the President suggests that it may be an internal communication that is part of the deliberative process. However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the decision-making process of government agencies by allowing them to freely exchange opinions and recommendations without fear of public disclosure. However, the Court also noted that the exemption is not absolute and must be narrowly construed, with any doubts resolved in favor of disclosure.; ; Therefore, if the record in question is determined to be a privileged communication within or between agencies that is part of the deliberative process, it may be protected under exemption 5. However, if there is any doubt as to whether the exemption applies, the record should be disclosed.

column5: The information in this record would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to contain internal communications between government officials discussing strategy and potential actions related to the sharing of prisoner data for the purpose of stopping benefits to prisoners and expanding those efforts to other agencies. This type of deliberative process is typically protected under exemption 5 in order to encourage open and candid discussions among government officials. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to engage in frank discussions without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the record appears to be an internal communication between government officials discussing potential actions and strategies related to the sharing of prisoner data. As such, it would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column5: No, the given text would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are deliberative in nature and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice that are part of the decision-making process. However, the given text does not contain any such deliberative information. It only lists four initiatives that ONDCP believes would benefit from the recipient's participation. Therefore, it does not fall under the scope of exemption 5.; ; Case law: In Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the court held that "Exemption 5 protects only those documents that are both predecisional and deliberative." Similarly, in Tax Analysts v. IRS, 117 F.3d 607, 617 (D.C. Cir. 1997), the court held that "Exemption 5 protects only those documents that would be privileged in the civil discovery context."

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? C. 20503 March 31, 1998; ; • The National "Rollout of the Youth Media Campaign: In early July, we will move from the 12 city pilot phase of the Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign into a national campaign (phase II). This expansion will bring our ads to every city and town across the nation. Already, the 12 city phase is showing results: anti-drug coalitions, whose phone numbers appear on the ads, report two to three times as many calls as received prior to the campaign; and, our buying service reports an unprecedented 100 percent match ratio of ad time to PSA time from media outlets. We expect to see the same types of results this time nationwide -- come July. Your participation in a national rollout event would increase the campaign's visibility, helping it to get off to a strong start.

column5: The above document would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. As such, it is likely to be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is EPA v. Mink (1973), in which the Court held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional communications which reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process."; ; Overall, based on the language and context of the communication, as well as relevant case law, it is likely that the above statement would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: It is possible that the above communication could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The mention of a "scheduling memo" and a request for a reaction from the recipient, who is a member of the Executive Office of the President, suggests that the communication may involve internal deliberations or advice related to the President's schedule or decision-making process. However, without more information about the content of the memo and the specific privilege being asserted, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is In re Sealed Case, 121 F.3d 729 (D.C. Cir. 1997), which established a three-part test for determining whether a communication is protected under the deliberative process privilege. The test requires that the communication be (1) predecisional, meaning it was prepared before a final decision was made; (2) deliberative, meaning it reflects the give-and-take of the decision-making process; and (3) not otherwise available, meaning the information is not already in the public domain. If the communication meets all three criteria, it may be protected from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; Again, without more information about the specific content and context of the communication in question, it is difficult to say definitively whether it would be protected under exemption 5.

Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether exemption 5 would apply to this record.; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), which held that agencies must provide a detailed justification for withholding records under exemption 5, including a showing that the records are pre-decisional, deliberative, and privileged. Additionally, NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), established that exemption 5 applies only to documents that are part of the agency's decision-making process and that would not have been created but for the prospect of agency decision-making.

column5: Based on the information provided, it is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The mention of a "McCaffrey Memo" suggests that this record may contain internal communications related to policy or decision-making, which could be considered privileged. However, without more information about the content of the record and the context in which it was created, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant to this analysis is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege under exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The Court emphasized that the privilege is intended to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to engage in candid and frank discussions without fear of public disclosure.; ; In applying this standard to the present record, it would be important to consider whether the communication was part of a deliberative process aimed at formulating policy or making a decision, and whether disclosure of the communication would harm the quality of agency decision-making. If the record meets these criteria, it may be protected under exemption 5. However, if the communication is purely factual or administrative in nature, or if disclosure would not harm the agency's decision-making process, the exemption would not apply.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The email appears to be a communication between government officials discussing a speech given by a politician, and it is possible that the content of the speech or the officials' discussion of it could be considered privileged. However, without more information about the context and purpose of the email, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that could be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege under exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The Court emphasized that the privilege is intended to protect the quality of agency decision-making by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. However, the Court also noted that the privilege is not absolute and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure.; ; In this case, it is possible that the email could be considered part of the deliberative process of the officials involved, and therefore protected under exemption 5. However, the public interest in disclosure of government actions and policies related to drug enforcement and border security could also be significant, and would need to be weighed against any potential harm to the deliberative process.

column5: The above record would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The email appears to be a discussion between government officials about potentially leaking a directive and coordinating with a press release from a private organization. This type of internal communication and strategy discussion is likely considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The email in question appears to be an intra-agency communication and would likely not be available to a party other than the agency in litigation. Therefore, it would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column5: As an AI language model, I do not have access to case law or any other external sources of information. However, based on my understanding of FOIA exemption 5, the email message provided in the question may be protected under this exemption.; ; FOIA exemption 5 protects from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This exemption covers documents that are privileged, such as those that contain attorney-client communications, attorney work product, or deliberative process materials.; ; In the email message provided, the subject line mentions a "proposed drug 'blueprint'" and a "note to Speaker Gingrich." This suggests that the email may contain deliberative process materials, which are protected under exemption 5. Deliberative process materials are documents that are created as part of the decision-making process within an agency and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice. These materials are protected because they are considered essential to the decision-making process and their disclosure could inhibit frank and open discussion within the agency.; ; Therefore, based on the limited information provided, it is possible that the email message may be protected under FOIA exemption 5. column5: The information in this record would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between government officials discussing a proposed drug policy document and letter, and it is likely that the officials were providing advice or recommendations to each other in the course of their official duties. This type of communication is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to communicate candidly and freely without fear of public disclosure. This rationale would apply to the communication in the present record, which involves officials discussing a sensitive policy issue and providing advice to each other.; ; Therefore, absent any countervailing factors or exceptions, the information in this record would likely be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: It is possible that the memorandum and document mentioned in the message could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption includes materials that are considered deliberative or pre-decisional, meaning they were created in the process of developing policy or making decisions and are not yet final.; ; In this case, the memorandum appears to be a communication between two high-level officials within an agency, which could qualify as privileged. The document entitled "Blueprint for a Drug Free America" also suggests that it may be a draft or proposal for a policy, which would make it deliberative and potentially exempt.; ; However, it is important to note that exemption 5 is not absolute and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF FROM: Frank Raines SUBJECT: ONDCP Document Entitled "Blueprint for a Drug Free America"; ; Last week ONDCP circulated a draft document entitled "Blueprint for a Drug Free America." The document lays out "performance targets" for the conduct of the anti-drug abuse program in the next five - ten years. The targets and dates are aggressive. For example, among the targets are the following: 1) 50 percent reduction in the overall rate of illicit drug use in the U.S. by 2007; and 2) 50 percent reduction in the available supply of drugs in the U.S. by 2007. The document indicates that the proposed performance targets must be supported by funding if they are to be realized.
column5: The memorandum would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The memorandum in question does not fall under this exemption because it does not contain predecisional or deliberative information. Rather, it is a communication about a draft document that has already been circulated, and it discusses the proposed performance targets and the need for funding to achieve them. Therefore, the memorandum is not protected under FOIA exemption 5.; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion, as the memorandum is a straightforward communication about a draft document and does not contain any predecisional or deliberative information.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF FROM: Frank Raines SUBJECT: ONDCP Document Entitled "Blueprint for a Drug Free America"; ; We have no evidence that would suggest that the draft goals can be achieved without substantial increases in Federal drug budgets in 1999 and beyond. Several agencies have made similar complaints to ONDCP (e.g., Justice and Treasury). As such, release of the document would be problematic and would imply FY 1999 budgetary trade-offs not yet made in favor of anti-drug spending and against other domestic discretionary spending. We suggest that the document be withheld until after submission of the 1999 President's Budget, when all agencies must submit their performance plans and targets to Congress. Those plans must be directly linked to multi-year Presidential budget request levels.

column5: The memorandum itself would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, as it does not contain any privileged or confidential information related to the deliberative process of the government. Exemption 5 generally applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature, and that would be subject to disclosure if they were made public. ; ; In this case, the memorandum appears to be a routine communication between two government officials regarding a specific document, and does not contain any sensitive or confidential information that would justify withholding it from disclosure. Moreover, the fact that General McCaffrey is likely to be upset if the document is not released suggests that the information contained in the document is not privileged or confidential, and that there is a strong public interest in its disclosure.; ; Case law supports this conclusion. In Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 does not apply to documents that are "purely factual" and do not contain any deliberative or pre-decisional information. Similarly, in Tax Analysts v. IRS, 117 F.3d 607 (D.C. Cir. 1997), the court held that exemption 5 does not protect documents that are "factual and non-deliberative" in nature. ; ; Based on these precedents, it is unlikely that the memorandum in question would be protected under exemption 5, as it appears to be a routine communication that does not contain any privileged or confidential information related to the deliberative process of the government.

However, the ONDCP document entitled "Blueprint for a Drug Free America" may be protected under exemption 5 if it contains pre-decisional or deliberative information. ; ; FOIA exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This exemption is often used to protect documents that contain pre-decisional or deliberative information, such as recommendations, opinions, and advice given to agency decision-makers. ; ; In the case of NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are both pre-decisional and deliberative. The court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the decision-making process by allowing agency officials to freely discuss and debate various options without fear of public scrutiny. ; ; Therefore, whether the ONDCP document is protected under exemption 5 would depend on whether it contains pre-decisional or deliberative information. If it does, then it may be protected from disclosure under FOIA.
