column5: It is difficult to determine whether the records would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without more information about the content of the records. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The records in question appear to be communications between individuals within the Executive Office of the President (EOP) and the White House Office (WHO), which could potentially qualify as intra-agency communications. However, the content of the records is not provided, so it is unclear whether they contain information that would be exempt from disclosure under FOIA. ; ; Case law that may be relevant to this issue includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which established the "deliberative process privilege" as a component of FOIA exemption 5. This privilege protects documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice related to that decision-making process. The privilege is intended to encourage open and candid discussions among government officials by protecting their internal communications from public disclosure. However, the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in keeping the information confidential. ; ; Without more information about the content of the records in question, it is impossible to determine whether they would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

Towards a National Policy of Coerced Abstinence

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Christa Robinson 02/12/9805:21:48PM Record Type: Record To: Ann F. Lewis/WHO/EOP, Paul E. Begala/WHO/EOP, Bruce N. Reed/OPD/EOP cc: Elena Kagan/OPD/EOP, Michelle Crisci/WHO/EOP Subject: Radio Address; ; • Last week, Columbia University's Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse (CASA) released a study confirming the need for coerced abstinence and treatment in the criminal justice system. CASA' s study found that 1 .4 million offenders -- or 80% of the I. 7 million criminals in prison and jails -- were either high on drugs or alcohol when arrested, stole property to buy drugs, or have a history of drug and alcohol abuse. Many other studies also confirm that the majority of individuals in the criminal justice system have similar drug histories.

President Clinton directed the Attorney General to create a program to drug test federal criminal defendants. Operation Drug TEST (Testing, Effective Sanctions and Treatment) funded a pilot program to test defendants immediately upon their arrest. In FY 1997, data from 24 judicial districts indicated that 56% of defendants (9,308) were tested -- a dramatic increase over the 28% (4,929) of defendants tested in the previous year. There was also a 190% increase in drug treatment for defendants over the same period.

The text provided is not an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter, but rather a record of a communication between individuals within the Executive Office of the President (EOP) and the Office of the President (OPD) regarding a radio address by President Clinton. Additionally, the text does not contain any privileged or confidential information that would be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5. Therefore, the text would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. ; ; There is no case law cited to support this conclusion as the text provided does not contain any information that would be subject to FOIA exemption 5.

column5: It is unlikely that the above record would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a routine email discussing a radio address, and does not contain any legal advice or deliberative process that would qualify for exemption 5 protection.; ; There is no specific case law cited in this response, as the determination of whether a record is exempt under exemption 5 depends on the specific content and context of the record in question. However, courts have generally held that exemption 5 applies to records that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, and that the agency has a legitimate interest in protecting from disclosure in order to encourage candid and frank discussions within the agency. See, e.g., NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150-51 (1975); Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Dep't of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980).

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Reed/OPD/EOP cc: Elena Kagan/OPD/EOP, Michelle Crisci/WHO/EOP Subject: Radio Address; ; A. The President's action today builds on his strong record of accomplishment in this area. In 1996, the President launched the first comprehensive effort to address the drug problem in our state criminal justice systems. President Clinton fought for and signed legislation to require states-- whose criminal justice systems house the vast majority of drug dependent offenders-- to drug test prisoners and parolees as a condition of receiving federal prison grants. Under the President's initiative, states must submit comprehensive plans of drug testing and intervention for prisoners and parolees by March 1, 1998 and implement them by September 1, 1998.
column5: The provided record would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between White House officials discussing the President's actions and accomplishments in addressing the drug problem in state criminal justice systems. This type of communication is likely to be considered privileged and protected from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they are part of the decision-making process and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice. The record in question appears to fit this description, as it discusses the President's actions and initiatives in addressing the drug problem and may contain recommendations or advice on how to implement these initiatives.; ; Therefore, it is likely that the record would be protected under exemption 5 and not subject to disclosure under FOIA.

No. By law, states must develop and implement plans for drug testing and intervention as a condition of receiving federal prison construction grants. Today's action means that as part of those plans, states will need to add information on their existing prison drug use problem, and update that information annually. All 50 state correctional systems conducted some form of drug testing on their inmates last year; yet no comprehensive data exists on the prevalence on drug use in state prisons. Anecdotal reports have shown that certain systems, such as the District of Columbia's corrections department, have had difficulty keeping drugs out of prisons. The baseline information they provide will help us to chart states' progress to reduce drug use and availability in their prisons.

column5: The above document may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. This exemption applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. ; ; The use of the word "DRAFT" three times in the document suggests that it is not a final version and is still in the process of being revised or reviewed. This indicates that the document is predecisional and has not yet been finalized. Additionally, the subject matter of the document - a policy on zero tolerance for drug use and availability for offenders - suggests that it is a deliberative communication, as it likely contains discussions and considerations of various options and potential consequences.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that documents that are both predecisional and deliberative are protected under exemption 5. Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that a document is predecisional if it was "generated before the adoption of an agency policy" and deliberative if it "reflects the give-and-take of the consultative process." ; ; Therefore, it is likely that the above document would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

DRAFT; ; Nonetheless, much more can and needs to be done to continue to bring down drug use and increase public safety. With more than half the offenders in our criminal justice system estimated to have a substance abuse problem, enforcing coerced abstinence within the criminal justice system is critical to breaking the cycle of crime and drugs. My Administration consistently has promoted testing offenders and requiring treatment as a means of reducing recidivism and drug-related crime. We have worked to expand the number of Drug Courts throughout the country, increased the number of federal arrestees and prisoners who are tested and treated for drugs, and launched an innovative "Breaking the Cycle" initiative, which is a rigorous program of testing, treatment, supervision, and sanctions for offenders at all stages of the criminal justice process. Convicted offenders who undergo drug testing and treatment while incarcerated and after release are approximately twice as likely to stay drug- and crime-free as those offenders who do not receive testing and treatment. But when drug use inside prisons is ignored, the demand for drugs runs high. In this environment, correction officials struggle to keep their prisons drug-free. Often drugs are smuggled in by visitors; sometimes even by compromised correctional staff.

column5: It is possible that the draft document would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption includes materials that are part of the deliberative process, such as pre-decisional drafts and internal memoranda. ; ; However, whether or not this specific document would be protected would depend on the specific facts and circumstances surrounding its creation and distribution. For example, if the document was still in the early stages of development and had not yet been finalized or approved by agency officials, it may be considered a pre-decisional draft and therefore exempt from disclosure. ; ; On the other hand, if the document had already been finalized and was being circulated for implementation or dissemination, it may not be considered part of the deliberative process and therefore not protected under exemption 5. ; ; There is no specific case law cited in this scenario, so it is difficult to provide a more definitive answer without additional information.

Maloney/WHO/EDP cc: See the distribution list at the bottom of this message Subject: "Final Drug Directive"; ; To the best of my knowledge and efforts this has been signed off on by DOJ, ONDCP and WH Counsel. The new language also alludes to including probationers in bullets #1 and #2 (mine and ONDCP's addition; Justice is okay though).
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The mention of DOJ, ONDCP, and WH Counsel suggests that the communication is part of an inter-agency discussion or decision-making process, and the reference to "added language" and "bullets" implies that the text contains internal deliberations or recommendations. The fact that the language is described as "rhetorical flourishes" and "mine and ONDCP's addition" further suggests that it is part of an ongoing internal discussion rather than a final decision or policy. ; ; One case that supports this interpretation is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies," and that it applies to "predecisional" materials that are "deliberative in nature." Based on this precedent, it seems likely that the text in question would be considered exempt under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: The information in the message would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The message appears to be discussing a final drug directive and mentions communication with high-level officials, indicating that it may contain internal deliberations or advice. Additionally, the mention of speaking to Rahm (presumably Rahm Emanuel, a former White House Chief of Staff) suggests that the information may be related to sensitive policy decisions. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 149 (1975)), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to communicate candidly and freely without fear of public disclosure. ; ; Overall, the message appears to contain privileged internal communications related to policy decisions, and would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: It is unlikely that the above message would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The message appears to be a routine email discussing a directive on drug testing and treatment in state prisons, and does not contain any indication of legal advice or deliberative process. Without such elements, the message would not qualify for exemption 5 protection. ; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that "the privilege for inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums under Exemption 5 is limited to those documents which are both predecisional and deliberative." Similarly, NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150 (1975), stated that "the privilege is not absolute and can be overcome by a sufficient showing of need." In this case, there does not appear to be a sufficient showing of need to justify withholding the email under exemption 5.

column5: This communication would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The email appears to be discussing the drafting and dissemination of a directive on drug testing and treatment in state prisons, which could be considered part of the policymaking process. The email also mentions the involvement of high-level officials, including Rahm Emanuel and Joe Califano, which further suggests that the communication is part of the deliberative process. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), in which the D.C. Circuit held that emails discussing the drafting of a legal memorandum were protected under exemption 5 because they were part of the deliberative process.

The email appears to be an internal communication between government officials discussing the development of a directive on drug testing and treatment in state prisons. The email discusses the origins of the proposed directive and suggests a different mechanism for achieving the same goals. This type of communication would likely be considered deliberative and pre-decisional, and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are both pre-decisional and deliberative. The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the decision-making process by allowing government officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. The email in question appears to be exactly the type of communication that would fall within the scope of exemption 5, as it is both pre-decisional and deliberative in nature.
